# Pronouns

Egyptian pronouns seem to hint at a linguistic Bridge between Semitic/Berber- languages and European languages:  

|	Person	| Sign	| Suffix 	| Dependent 	| Cognates

# ante ğ“ˆ– ğ“ â€¦
Independent pronouns are prefixed by [ğ“ˆ–](ğ“ˆ–)[ğ“](ğ“) which is similar to latin **[ante](ante.html)-** or ğ“ˆ–ğ“ˆ–  'anna' as directional [An](Prepositions)rede (address), comparable with ancient greek á¼¦ÏƒÏ„ (n)este forms, Albanian un-Ã« and Hebrew an-i.

# ego < enkwo < ğ“Œğ“¡ğ“¢ urnkwo/nurkwo
ğ’€€ğ’ˆ¾ğ’†ª a-na-ku < [ante](ante.html)-Icku  

The complicated form for "I" ğ“Œğ“¡[ğ“¢](ğ“¢.html) urkwoÊ³ is echoed in  
Gothic ğŒ¿ğŒ²ğŒºğŒ°ğ‚ ugkar and Hittite ğ’Œ‘[ğ’ŠŒ](Geier) â€¢wekhoÊ³ > [ego](ego.html) Ick, Ich, wez (us,our) ğ’Œ¦ UKUâ‚ƒ UNG uÅ‹â‚ƒ ğ“Œâ¿urn  

In it's old reading ğ“Œ nur > urn ğ“Œ it reads as :  
ğ“Œğ“¡[ğ“¢](ğ“¢.html) urnkwo > anaku ğ’€€ğ’ˆ¾ğ’†ª [ante](ante.html) Ich ×Ö¸× ×•Ö¹×›Ö´×™ Ê¾ÄnÃ´á¸µÃ® æˆ‘ ngo5 and Phoenician ğ¤€ğ¤ğ¤Š Ê¾nk ğ¤€ğ¤ğ¤Šğ¤‰ Ê¾nky â€œIâ€ ğ“‡‹ğ“€€ ğ’¹ğ’†ª Ä¨ku  

The first person form is irregular with variants of  
[ğ“…±](ğ“…±)ğ“¡[ğ“€€](ğ“€€) Ã¼ck,ego,ich,eghwo,wogo, Äuğ’ˆ¬,Äağ’‚·,ğ€ğğ‹, an'ich, nik, nga æˆ‘ < ante.yo  â˜‘!  
ğ“…±[ğ“€€](ğ“€€) own wo æˆ‘ we ma à¤® moi,à¦®à¦‡,mon,Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ½ÑŒ, man, Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ½ min,mine,manch,mich,moi,â²™â²™â²Ÿâ³¼ â€¦ ğ€ğ ^^  
ğ“…±[ğ“€€](ğ“€€) ami ğ¤ ğ¤ªğ¤° amu ğŠšğŠğŠ’ áº½mu ğ€ğ AnI unÃ«  áŠ¥áŠ” (Ê¾É™ne) Ø£ÙÙ†ÙØ§ Ê¾anÄ Ã¦na ×× × inÄ ÜÜ¢Ü naya an-yo Ente.I ante-I [AmBi](ambi)  
ğ“€€ â²™â²™â²“â²› â²™â²™â²“â²›â²‰ â²™â²™â²Ÿâ³¼ (my)self â‡” mono, mine, moi  

Ente ğ“…± ÄuÄa ğ’ˆ¬ğ’‚· ğ“…± ğŠšğŠğŠ’ áº½mu ğ“†‚ niÇo é¸Ÿ ğ“ˆ–ğ“‡‹ğ“…±ğ“…¦  !  

It belongs to the Eurasian superfamilies which use m,w,n,g for first person consonants, but not say b,l,r,t (at least not in a leading position). Like "[mama](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mama_and_papa)" it might be anatomically prewired though.  

# dyuk / kyut
Astonishingly the second person is perfectly attested in [Gothic](Gothic.html): ğ“¡ğ“ğ“¢ ğŒ¾ğŒ¿ğ„ áµyou-two  [ğ“¡](ğ“¡.html) [ğŒ¾](ğŒ¾.html)  

The compound form ğ“ ğ“…± ğ“¡ Dich â‹ Õ¤Õ¸Ö‚Ö„  dukÊ° â‹ ØªÙƒ tak combines t&k [ğ“](ğ“)&[ğ“¡](ğ“¡),  
as does [Kartvelian](Kartvelian.html)  áƒ—áƒ¥áƒ•áƒ”áƒœ (tkven) < ğ“ [ğ“…±](ğ“…±.html) ğ“¿ ğ“ˆ– ğ“¥ ( Du Dein / Dir Dein / die Deinigen... )  

# old forms
The hypothesized ancient forms of the â€˜lettersâ€™  ğ“†‘ ğ“¡ ğ“‡‹ ğ“…± (see [Alphabet](Alphabet) and [Axioms](Axioms)) with slight shifts and dangling connotations play well into the above table:  
[ğ“†‘](ğ“†‘) Ï† pthnâ‹s*n:  Ï†Î¯Î´Î¹n python snake [usually simply transcribed as â€˜fâ€™]  
[ğ“¡](ğ“¡) *tcu: Kelle/cup/tasse [alt] vs jug, jar  
[ğ“‡‹](ğ“‡‹) *fe feather/vieh â‡¨ ve / we  
[ğ“…±](ğ“…±) ÂµÏ‰:= u, uu, w, â€˜un, â€˜en, mwn

The following are the personal pronouns of Mehri, an extant language spoken in Yemen & Oman:  

person|english|Mehri|EG|IE  
------|-------|-----|--|--  
1st sg. 		|"I" 	|hÅh -Ä«  |ğ“‡‹|ich I  
2nd sg. masc. 	|"you" 	 	|-(A)k  |ğ“¡|kyou?  
3rd sg. masc. 	|"he" 	 	|-(A)h  |ğ“†‘|he (phy who)  
3rd sg. fem. 	|"she" 	 	|-(A)s  |ğ“‹´|she  
1st pl.		 |"we" 	|ná¸¥ah -an	|ğ“ˆ–ğ“ª|nous uns  
2nd pl. fem. 	|"you" 	|tÄn -kan	|ğ“¿ğ“ª|thine  
3rd pl. fem. 	|"they" 	|sÄn -san|ğ“‹´ğ“ª|them, seine  

This paradigma has an astonishing alignment with the Egyptian pronouns, and with english / â€˜Europeanâ€™ pronouns for that matter! It also reflects the t/c/k ğ“ğ“¿ğ“¡ shift for 'thy'.  
Mehri sounded foreign â€˜barbaricâ€™ to al-Hamdani, a well versed Arabic geographer -945 A.D, suggesting that it was not Northwest-Semitic.  

The basic pronouns align well with PIE (especially Spanish, English and German),  
However the Egyptian forms align even better with Berber dialects, warranting the long held association with Afroasiatic (Semitic-Hamitic) languages:  
Berber  nat/nathâ‹nas: natche (ğ“ˆ–ğ“-je) natta (ğ“ˆ–ğ“-ta) nasse (ğ“ˆ–ğ“-she)  

Again, this may not forbid links to European languages, rather hint to basal Egyptian intermediate or root forms.  

Kartvelian languages belong to the same superfamily :  
In the context of Maykop, the central new puzzle-piece in the formation of urbanization, allow us to compare the Kartvelian paradigm (e.g. Georgian):  

|	Person	|Suffix  	| Kartvelian	| Dependent 	| Cognates  
|----------------|-------|---------------|---------------|---------------  
1st s. 		|ğ“‡‹	|me 	| 	[ğ“…±](ğ“…±)	|I,je,ich,we,wo,wir,[ğ“…±](ğ“…±),me,my  
2nd s.m. 	|ğ“¡	|she(n) 	|ğ“[ğ“¢](ğ“¢) tu(n) 		|thou,tu,Du,Seineâ€¦(majestic)  
2nd s.f. 	|ğ“	|she(n) 	|ğ“ğ“ˆ– tÉ™n 		|ta,tien,Deine  
3rd s.m. 	|[ğ“†‘](ğ“†‘)	|es 	|ğ“‡“ğ“¢ su		|phe,phis,son,sein,su,es  
3rd s.f. 	|ğ“‹´	|es,eg 	|ğ“‹´,Î“	 		|she, sie, es  
1st p. 		|ğ“ˆ–ğ“ª	|áƒ©áƒ•áƒ”áƒœ Ävenu 	|ğ“ˆ–ğ“¥ nus 		|nu[ğ“¢](ğ“¢),nous,uns,on  
2nd p. 		|ğ“ğ“ˆ–ğ“ª/ğ“¡ğ“ˆ–ğ“¥ |tkven! 	|ğ“ğ“ˆ–ğ“¥ tnğ“¥ 		|ton,thine  
3rd p. 		|ğ“‹´ğ“ˆ–ğ“ª	|eseni 	|ğ“‹´ğ“ˆ–ğ“¥ snğ“¥ 		|semnâ‹them (their)  

note the second person plural ğ“ğ“¡ğ“ˆ–ğ“ª tkven, being the perfect intermediate between Egyptian ğ“ğ“ˆ–ğ“ª and ğ“¡ğ“ˆ–ğ“¥.  

Is it possible that Kartvelian languages belong to the same superfamily?  
Through intense contact, people of different genetical and linguistic background can adopt not just loanwords and [wanderwords](wanderwords) but even grammatical features. We propose that PIE and Semitic were both heavily influenced by the pioneers of the copper revolution, with their early centers in Varna and Maykop, Caucasia.  

[ğ“](ğ“)[ğ“¿](ğ“¿) as th/c is forgivably cose to 'sh'  
Also note the [pluralis maiestatis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_we)  
We [ğ“…±](ğ“…±) æˆ‘  
Dein ğ“ğ“ˆ– ğ“¿[ğ“ˆ–](ğ“ˆ–) ShenÇ ä½   

Looking at [Uralic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finnish_grammar), the idea of a [Nostratic](Nostratic) core structure seems very plausible.  

Contrast this beautiful alignment with [Turk](Turk) grammar.  

Oddity: compare Berber natta - Ù‡Ùˆ  with ğ“†‘ Ï† pthnâ‹s*n:  Ï†Î¯Î´Î¹n python snake  

ğ“ ğ“„¿  der / dlar : reflexive 'that'

The second person has strong connections to "[Your](https://github.com/pannous/hieros/wiki/%F0%92%86%AA) [honor](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/honor#Translations) / my esteemed" â‡” Timo deem Ï„Î¹Î¼Î®  German 'Anerkennung' might preserve or reflect old forms as [ğ’†ª](ğ’†ª.html)[ğ’‰¡](ğ’‰¡.html)  

The transition between the slightly xenotic second person Du Tu Cu and French vous is perfectly captured in arabian  Ø¸Ø± which is transcribed as DHuu but pronounced more like vous.
